journal.py fcmaes/journal.py Go to the documentation of this file.00001 # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- 00002 """ 00003 ============================================================================= 00004 00005 Fast CMA-ES - version 1.6.11 00006 00007 (c) 2025 – Dietmar Wolz 00008 (c) 2025 – Latitude 00009 00010 License: MIT 00011 00012 File: 00013 - journal.py 00014 00015 Description: 00016 - Simple Optuna Journal file generating wrapper for single and 00017 multiple objective fcmaes objective functions. 00018 Can be used to gain live insight into a long running optimization process. 00019 - Warning: Only use for slow Hyperparameter optimizations, otherwise the journal file will grow too big. 00020 - Usage example: [2]; See [3], [4]. 00021 install optuna-dashboard 00022 - pip install optuna-dashboard 00023 optional: 00024 - pip install optuna-fast-fanova gunicorn 00025 Then call: 00026 - optuna-dashboard <path_to_journalfile> 00027 In your browser open: 00028 - http://127.0.0.1:8080/ 00029 00030 00031 00032 00033 Authors: 00034 - Dietmar Wolz 00035 - romain.despoullains@latitude.eu 00036 - corentin.generet@latitude.eu 00037 00038 References: 00039 - [1] https://github.com/dietmarwo/fast-cma-es 00040 - [2] https://github.com/dietmarwo/fast-cma-es/blob/master/examples/prophet_opt.py 00041 - [3] https://optuna-dashboard.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting-started.html 00042 - [4] https://optuna.readthedocs.io/en/latest/tutorial/20_recipes/011_journal_storage.html 00043 00044 Documentation: 00045 - 00046 00047 00048 ============================================================================= 00049 """ 00050 00051 00052 from dataclasses import dataclass, asdict 00053 from typing import List, Dict, Any 00054 from scipy.optimize import Bounds 00055 import numpy as np 00056 import multiprocessing as mp 00057 from multiprocessing import Manager 00058 import ctypes as ct 00059 import json 00060 import sys 00061 00062 from datetime import datetime 00063 00064 @dataclass 00065 class Base_message: 00066 """ 00067 Represents the base structure of a message. 00068 00069 This class serves as a base for creating message objects. It defines common 00070 attributes that are essential for message handling, such as operation code and 00071 worker identifier. Intended to be used as a foundational data structure for 00072 various message-related operations. 00073 00074 Attributes: 00075 op_code (int): The operation code indicating the type or purpose of 00076 the message. 00077 worker_id (str): The unique identifier corresponding to the worker 00078 associated with the message. 00079 """ 00080 op_code: int 00081 worker_id: str 00082 00083 @dataclass 00084 class Study_start(Base_message): 00085 """ 00086 Represents the initial message to start a study. 00087 00088 This class is used to define the starting parameters of a study. 00089 It holds critical information such as the name of the study and the 00090 directions for the study. The class ensures clear encapsulation of 00091 necessary data to initiate and guide the study process. 00092 00093 Attributes: 00094 study_name (str): Name of the study. 00095 directions (List[int]): A list of integers representing the 00096 directions for the study. 00097 """ 00098 study_name: str 00099 directions: List[int] 00100 00101 @dataclass 00102 class Trial_start(Base_message): 00103 """ 00104 Represents the start of a trial within a specific study. 00105 00106 Provides details about the study identifier and the start date-time 00107 when the trial began. 00108 00109 Attributes: 00110 study_id (int): Unique identifier of the study associated with 00111 the trial. 00112 datetime_start (str): Start date and time of the trial in ISO 00113 date-time format. 00114 """ 00115 study_id: int 00116 datetime_start: str # ISO format date-time 00117 00118 @dataclass 00119 class Trial_param(Base_message): 00120 """ 00121 Represents the parameters associated with a specific trial. 00122 00123 This class is used to encapsulate details about a single trial parameter, with 00124 its unique identifier, name, internal value, and associated distribution. 00125 It extends from the Base_message class. 00126 00127 Attributes: 00128 trial_id (int): Unique identifier for the trial to which this parameter belongs. 00129 param_name (str): Name of the trial parameter. 00130 distribution (Dict[str, Any]): A dictionary defining the distribution of the parameter values. 00131 """ 00132 trial_id: int 00133 param_name: str 00134 param_value_internal: float 00135 distribution: Dict[str, Any] # Represented as a dictionary 00136 00137 @dataclass 00138 class Trial_value(Base_message): 00139 """Represents the value of a single trial in an experiment. 00140 00141 This class is used to encapsulate and manage data regarding a specific 00142 trial, including its unique identifier, state, associated values, and 00143 completion date and time. It is intended to facilitate organization and 00144 manipulation of trial-related data, often in the context of optimization 00145 experiments or similar workflows. 00146 00147 Attributes: 00148 trial_id (int): The unique identifier of the trial. 00149 state (int): The current state of the trial, typically represented 00150 as an integer mapping to specific status codes. 00151 values (List[float]): A list of values or outcomes associated with 00152 the trial. These could represent results of the trial or 00153 metrics of evaluation. 00154 datetime_complete (str): The completion date and time of the trial 00155 represented in ISO 8601 format. 00156 """ 00157 trial_id: int 00158 state: int 00159 values: List[float] 00160 datetime_complete: str # ISO format date-time 00161 00162 def message_to_json(message): 00163 """ 00164 Converts a given message object to its JSON representation. 00165 00166 This function serializes a message object based on its type. If the message type is 00167 `Trial_param`, its `distribution` field is serialized as a JSON string before converting 00168 the entire object to JSON format. For other message types, the object is directly 00169 converted to JSON format. 00170 00171 Args: 00172 message: The message object to be serialized to JSON. 00173 00174 Returns: 00175 str: A JSON string representation of the message. 00176 """ 00177 if isinstance(message, Trial_param): 00178 data = asdict(message) 00179 # Serialize 'distribution' field as JSON string 00180 data['distribution'] = json.dumps(data['distribution']) 00181 return json.dumps(data, separators=(',', ':')) 00182 else: 00183 data = asdict(message) 00184 return json.dumps(data, separators=(',', ':')) 00185 00186 def distribution(low, high): 00187 """ 00188 Generates a JSON representation of a float distribution within a specified range. 00189 00190 The function creates a JSON object representing a uniform float distribution 00191 with specified lower and upper bounds. The resulting JSON is parsed and returned 00192 as a Python dictionary. 00193 00194 Args: 00195 low (float): The lower bound of the distribution range. 00196 high (float): The upper bound of the distribution range. 00197 00198 Returns: 00199 dict: A dictionary representation of the float distribution. 00200 """ 00201 distribution_str = f'{{"name": "FloatDistribution", "attributes": {{"step": null, "low": {low}, "high": {high}, "log": false}}}}' 00202 return json.loads(distribution_str) 00203 00204 def study_start(worker_id, study_name, dir): 00205 """ 00206 Creates and returns a JSON representation of a study start message. 00207 00208 This function builds a study start message using provided worker identification, 00209 study name, and study directions. If the `dir` parameter is scalar, it is converted 00210 into a list; otherwise, it is used as is. The message is then serialized into a 00211 JSON string for further communication or processing. 00212 00213 Args: 00214 worker_id (int): Unique identifier for the worker initiating the study. 00215 study_name (str): Name of the study being started. 00216 dir (Union[str, List[str]]): Direction(s) for the study. Can be a single 00217 direction (string) or a list of directions. 00218 00219 Returns: 00220 str: JSON-encoded representation of the constructed study start message. 00221 """ 00222 msg = Study_start( 00223 op_code=0, 00224 worker_id=worker_id, 00225 study_name=study_name, 00226 directions=[dir] if np.isscalar(dir) else dir, 00227 ) 00228 return message_to_json(msg) 00229 00230 def trial_param(worker_id, trial_id, param_name, param_value_internal, low, high): 00231 """ 00232 Generates a JSON message containing trial parameter details. 00233 00234 This function creates a message using the given trial parameters and returns 00235 its JSON representation. The message contains information such as worker ID, 00236 trial ID, parameter name, internal parameter value, and the specified 00237 distribution range. 00238 00239 Args: 00240 worker_id: The unique identifier for the worker. 00241 trial_id: The unique identifier for the trial. 00242 param_name: The name of the parameter. 00243 param_value_internal: The internal value of the parameter to be passed. 00244 low: The lower bound of the parameter's range. 00245 high: The upper bound of the parameter's range. 00246 00247 Returns: 00248 str: A JSON-formatted string with the details of the trial parameter. 00249 """ 00250 msg = Trial_param( 00251 op_code=5, 00252 worker_id=worker_id, 00253 trial_id=trial_id, 00254 param_name=str(param_name), 00255 param_value_internal=param_value_internal, 00256 distribution=distribution(low, high) 00257 ) 00258 return message_to_json(msg) 00259 00260 def trial_start(worker_id, study_id): 00261 """ 00262 Starts a trial by recording the worker ID, study ID, and the current timestamp, and 00263 generates a JSON message representation of the trial start event. 00264 00265 Args: 00266 worker_id (int): Unique identifier for the worker initiating the trial. 00267 study_id (int): Unique identifier for the study related to the trial. 00268 00269 Returns: 00270 str: JSON representation of the trial start event. 00271 """ 00272 datetime_str = datetime.now().isoformat() 00273 msg = Trial_start( 00274 op_code=4, 00275 worker_id=worker_id, 00276 study_id=study_id, 00277 datetime_start=datetime_str 00278 ) 00279 return message_to_json(msg) 00280 00281 def trial_value(worker_id, trial_id, y): 00282 """ 00283 Creates and returns a JSON representation of a trial value message. 00284 00285 The function generates a message object for a specific trial and worker, 00286 incorporating information about the trial's state, its values, and a 00287 timestamp indicating when the operation was completed. It converts the 00288 message to a JSON format before returning. 00289 00290 Args: 00291 worker_id (int): Identifier for the worker responsible for the trial. 00292 trial_id (int): Identifier for the specific trial whose value is being 00293 processed. 00294 y (Union[float, list[float]]): Numeric value(s) associated with the trial. 00295 This can be a scalar value or a list of values. 00296 00297 Returns: 00298 str: JSON string representation of the trial value message. 00299 """ 00300 datetime_str = datetime.now().isoformat() 00301 msg = Trial_value( 00302 op_code=6, 00303 worker_id=worker_id, 00304 trial_id=trial_id, 00305 state=1, 00306 values=[y] if np.isscalar(y) else y, 00307 datetime_complete=datetime_str 00308 ) 00309 return message_to_json(msg) 00310 00311 class Journal: 00312 """ 00313 Handles logging of study, trial, parameter, and value information to a file. 00314 00315 This class facilitates logging structured data for studies and their associated 00316 trials into a file. Each method corresponds to specific types of log entries such 00317 as study start, trial start, trial parameters, and trial values. It ensures the 00318 data is written in real-time and provides methods for handling batch operations 00319 where multiple workers or trials need to be recorded. 00320 00321 Attributes: 00322 filename (str): Path to the file where journal entries are logged. 00323 file (TextIO): File object used for writing journal entries. 00324 """ 00325 def __init__(self, filename, study_name, dir): 00326 """ 00327 Initializes an instance for managing file operations and conducting initial study setup. 00328 00329 Args: 00330 filename (str): Name of the file to be created and written into. 00331 study_name (str): Name of the study to be initialized in the setup process. 00332 dir (str): Directory path for the study workspace or initialization. 00333 """ 00334 self.filename = filename 00335 self.file = open(self.filename, 'w') 00336 self.study("main", study_name, dir) 00337 00338 def study(self, worker_id, study_name, dir): 00339 """ 00340 Writes the start of a study to a file. 00341 00342 This method appends a formatted string, indicating the start of a study, 00343 to the specified file and flushes the file buffer to ensure the data is 00344 written to disk immediately. 00345 00346 Args: 00347 worker_id: Worker identifier as a string or integer. 00348 study_name: Name of the study as a string. 00349 dir: Directory or path related to the study as a string. 00350 """ 00351 self.file.write(study_start(worker_id, study_name, dir) + '
') 00352 self.file.flush() # Ensure that data is written to disk 00353 00354 def trial(self, worker_id, study_id): 00355 """ 00356 Initiates a trial session by logging the start of the trial and ensuring 00357 that the log data is immediately written to disk. 00358 00359 Args: 00360 worker_id: Unique identifier for the worker participating in the trial. 00361 study_id: Unique identifier for the study to which the trial belongs. 00362 """ 00363 self.file.write(trial_start(worker_id, study_id) + '
') 00364 self.file.flush() # Ensure that data is written to disk 00365 00366 def param(self, worker_id, trial_id, param_name, param_value_internal, low, high): 00367 """ 00368 Writes a parameter value to the associated file for a given trial and worker. 00369 00370 This method serializes the parameter information using the `trial_param` 00371 function and writes the resulting string representation to the file object 00372 associated with this class. Additionally, it ensures that the data is promptly 00373 written to disk. 00374 00375 Args: 00376 worker_id: Identifier of the worker requesting the execution. 00377 trial_id: Identifier of the trial being executed. 00378 param_name: Name of the parameter to be used in the computation. 00379 param_value_internal: Internal representation or reference of the parameter value. 00380 low: The lower bound of the parameter's acceptable range. 00381 high: The upper bound of the parameter's acceptable range. 00382 """ 00383 self.file.write(trial_param(worker_id, trial_id, param_name, param_value_internal, low, high) + '
') 00384 self.file.flush() # Ensure that data is written to disk 00385 00386 def value(self, worker_id, trial_id, y): 00387 """ 00388 Writes the trial value to a file and ensures that data is written to disk. 00389 00390 Args: 00391 worker_id: Identifier for the worker. 00392 trial_id: Identifier for the trial. 00393 y: Value associated with the trial. 00394 00395 """ 00396 self.file.write(trial_value(worker_id, trial_id, y) + '
') 00397 self.file.flush() # Ensure that data is written to disk 00398 00399 def write_x(self, worker_id, trial_id, x, bounds): 00400 """ 00401 Writes parameter values for a given trial and worker. 00402 00403 This method iterates through the input vector `x` and assigns parameter values 00404 for corresponding indices, using lower and upper bounds provided in `bounds`. 00405 00406 Args: 00407 worker_id: Identifier for the worker. 00408 trial_id: Identifier for the trial. 00409 x: List or array of parameter values. 00410 bounds: Object containing lower (`lb`) and upper (`ub`) bounds for the parameters. 00411 """ 00412 for i, xi in enumerate(x): 00413 self.param(worker_id, trial_id, i, xi, bounds.lb[i], bounds.ub[i]) 00414 00415 def write_xs(self, trial_id, xs, bounds): 00416 """ 00417 Writes a set of parameter values (xs) for different workers associated with a trial. 00418 00419 This method distributes parameter values to workers by iterating through the 00420 list `xs`. Each parameter value in `xs` is assigned to a worker identified by 00421 an incremental ID. The `write_x` method is invoked for each worker, linking the 00422 trial, worker, and provided bounds. 00423 00424 Args: 00425 trial_id (int): Identifier for the trial to which the parameters belong. 00426 xs (list): A list of parameter values to be assigned to workers. 00427 bounds (tuple): Bounds within which the parameter values are constrained. 00428 """ 00429 for worker_id, x in enumerate(xs): 00430 self.write_x(str(worker_id+1), trial_id+worker_id, x, bounds) 00431 00432 def write_ys(self, trial_id, ys): 00433 """ 00434 Writes a list of values to corresponding trial IDs for all workers. 00435 00436 Args: 00437 trial_id (int): The base trial ID to which worker IDs and their corresponding 00438 values will be associated. 00439 ys (list): A list of values to be written for each worker. The values in this 00440 list correspond to workers incrementally starting from worker ID 1. 00441 """ 00442 for worker_id, y in enumerate(ys): 00443 self.value(str(worker_id+1), trial_id+worker_id, y) 00444 00445 def write_starts(self, study_id, batch_size): 00446 """ 00447 Executes a series of trials for a given study ID. 00448 00449 The method iterates over a range defined by the batch size and performs trials 00450 by invoking the `trial` method with the respective worker ID and study ID. 00451 00452 Args: 00453 study_id (str): The identifier of the study being processed. 00454 batch_size (int): The number of workers/trials to execute. 00455 """ 00456 for worker_id in range(batch_size): 00457 self.trial(str(worker_id+1), study_id) 00458 00459 def close(self): 00460 """ 00461 Closes the associated file resource. 00462 00463 This method safely closes the file resource associated with the instance, 00464 ensuring that any resources tied to it are properly released. It is crucial 00465 to call this method after completion of file operations to avoid resource 00466 leaks or locking issues. 00467 00468 Raises: 00469 IOError: If an I/O operation error occurs while closing the file. 00470 """ 00471 self.file.close() 00472 00473 class journal_wrapper(object): 00474 """ 00475 A wrapper class for handling journaling operations related to batch processing in a 00476 parallelized optimization or search study. 00477 00478 This class is responsible for managing concurrent journal entries that include trial 00479 start information, parameters, and trial evaluation results. It coordinates the storage, 00480 formatting, and writing of trial-related data into a journal file to support analytics 00481 or dashboards for the study. Synchronization mechanisms ensure thread-safe operations 00482 in multi-process environments. 00483 00484 Attributes: 00485 fit (callable): A function that evaluates the input parameters `x` and returns the 00486 corresponding result. 00487 bounds (object): An object that contains lower (`lb`) and upper (`ub`) bounds for 00488 parameters. 00489 journal (Journal): An instance of the `Journal` class used for managing and writing 00490 to the journal file. 00491 study_id (str): A unique identifier for the entire study. 00492 batch_size (int): The number of trials to process in a batch. 00493 """ 00494 00495 def __init__(self, fit, bounds, jfname, study_name, study_id, batch_size): 00496 """ 00497 Initializes the object with the given parameters and sets up the required attributes. 00498 00499 Args: 00500 fit: Callable to perform fitting or evaluation tasks. 00501 bounds: Iterable specifying the bounds or constraints for the fitting 00502 or evaluation process. 00503 jfname: String specifying the file name for the journal. 00504 study_name: String representing the name of the study. 00505 study_id: Integer representing the identifier of the study. 00506 batch_size: Integer representing the batch size to be used. 00507 """ 00508 self.fit = fit 00509 self.bounds = bounds 00510 self.journal = Journal(jfname, study_name, 1) 00511 self.study_id = study_id 00512 self.batch_size = batch_size 00513 self.trial_id = mp.RawValue(ct.c_int, 0) 00514 self.lock = mp.Lock() 00515 self.mgr = Manager() 00516 self.reset() 00517 00518 def reset(self): 00519 """ 00520 Resets the lists managed by the instance. 00521 00522 This method reinitializes the lists `starts`, `xs`, and `ys` using the 00523 manager object to ensure they are shared lists in multiprocess scenarios. 00524 00525 Args: 00526 None 00527 00528 Returns: 00529 None 00530 """ 00531 self.starts = self.mgr.list() 00532 self.xs = self.mgr.list() 00533 self.ys = self.mgr.list() 00534 00535 def store_start(self, worker_id, study_id): 00536 """ 00537 Stores the start of a trial by appending the formatted trial start string 00538 to the `starts` collection. This function helps track when each trial begins 00539 for a given worker and study. 00540 00541 Args: 00542 worker_id: Identifier for the worker who starts the trial. 00543 study_id: Identifier for the study associated with the trial. 00544 """ 00545 self.starts.append(trial_start(worker_id, study_id) + '
') 00546 00547 def store_x(self, worker_id, trial_id, x): 00548 """ 00549 Stores the parameters of a specific trial for a worker. 00550 00551 This method takes the worker ID, trial ID, and a list of parameters, formats 00552 them according to the trial's bounds, and appends the formatted string to the 00553 internal storage for later use. 00554 00555 Args: 00556 worker_id: The ID of the worker to associate with the parameters. 00557 trial_id: The ID of the trial to associate with the parameters. 00558 x: A list of numerical parameters to be stored for the given worker and 00559 trial. 00560 """ 00561 x_str = '' 00562 for i, xi in enumerate(x): 00563 x_str += trial_param(worker_id, trial_id, i, xi, self.bounds.lb[i], self.bounds.ub[i]) + '
' 00564 self.xs.append(x_str) 00565 00566 def store_y(self, worker_id, trial_id, y): 00567 """ 00568 Stores the provided `y` value, associated with a worker and trial ID, in the list of `ys`. 00569 00570 Args: 00571 worker_id (int): The unique identifier of the worker. 00572 trial_id (int): The unique identifier of the trial. 00573 y (Any): The value to store, associated with the worker and trial. 00574 00575 """ 00576 self.ys.append(trial_value(worker_id, trial_id, y) + '
') 00577 00578 #we need to reorder the journal output to get the dashboard working 00579 def __call__(self, x): 00580 """ 00581 Executes the callable functionality, managing and processing a batch of inputs 00582 and outputs concurrently, while ensuring proper thread safety and data 00583 handling. 00584 00585 Args: 00586 x: Input value to process and fit. 00587 00588 Returns: 00589 The processed output value as a result of `fit(x)`. If an exception occurs, 00590 returns the maximum possible float value as defined in `sys.float_info.max`. 00591 00592 Raises: 00593 Not explicitly raised in documentation but exceptions are caught 00594 within the method. 00595 """ 00596 try: 00597 with self.lock: 00598 n = self.batch_size 00599 if len(self.ys) >= n: 00600 for i in range(n): 00601 self.journal.file.write(self.starts.pop(0)) 00602 for i in range(n): 00603 self.journal.file.write(self.xs.pop(0)) 00604 for i in range(n): 00605 self.journal.file.write(self.ys.pop(0)) 00606 self.journal.file.flush() 00607 trial_id = self.trial_id.value 00608 self.trial_id.value += 1 00609 00610 worker_id = str(trial_id % self.batch_size) 00611 self.store_start(worker_id, self.study_id) 00612 self.store_x(worker_id, trial_id, x) 00613 y = self.fit(x) 00614 self.store_y(worker_id, trial_id, y) 00615 return y 00616 except Exception as ex: 00617 print(str(ex)) 00618 return sys.float_info.max 00619
